job_title: Degree Works Specialist in Pompano Beach, FL
pros:
Time off, hourly employees: 2 weeks vacation first two years, 3 weeks in years three through five, 4 weeks starting in year six. 
Time off, salaried employees: 22 days per year
3 personal days per year
Sick time accrues every paycheck until a maximum of 22 days. 

At the beginning of the pandemic, most employees were allowed to work remotely from home. 

Paid time off during institution closure between Christmas and New Years.

Tuition discount for employees seeking degrees at NSU.

Health insurance offers money back (up to $230) based on completing healthy measures such as exercise, annual physicals, smoking cessation, or attending hour-long workshops.

Employees are discouraged from talking about controversial topics at work. 

Employees have diverse backgrounds.
cons:
Low pay compared to other institutions. 

Hourly employees punch a clock, salaried employees are overworked. The institution created a third type of employee called co-ordinator. They might be paid hourly or salaried. 

Co-workers are not notified if a person tests positive for COVID19.

No one is allowed to work remotely from home even though many jobs don't involve a reason to be on campus. 

Traffic getting to the Davie campus is awful when school is in session. Employees must pay for parking on campus.

 in order to get around a federal mandate to pay salaried employees a higher wage, salaried employees were re-classified.

NSU is not just a non-profit organization. It has a for-profit wing. It was created after the university purchased a nearby golf course.

There's a lot of paperwork involved in using more than three days of sick time.

There's no incentive to remain in one job. Pay raises are low and happen once every 1.5 years for all employees at the same time since I started. Although a position may have a salary range, you won't hit the top of it unless you work there for decades. You need to change positions every two years to increase your salary meaningfully. 

Annual reviews are mandatory, happen for all employees at the same time, and are done by rote. There isn't much personalization. Every year I ask my supervisor where I might improve and I get an avoidance answer. It's very different from private companies. 

Some managers treat you like an adult while others are by-the-book, no exceptions. For instance, if there's a traffic accident and you're late, one manager might let you make up the time missed by shortening the lunch hour while another will say no, it's against their policy.

pros: The average person who works there is timid and easy to get along with. There is a free week off around Christmas for all employees, and there are plenty of places around to go for lunch
cons:
NSU is a stagnant organization that uses incredibly irrelevant technology compared to the wider business world combined with a complete lack of modern development practices,
below average pay, and cronyism in management. The quality of education NSU provides is also subpar, the school is embroiled in numerous lawsuits revolving around delaying PHD candidates from finishing degrees in order to extort more tuition money.

This was my first job out of college so I did not really have anything to compare it to professionally but I have since found much better more fulfilling jobs, if you work here
as a developer be aware that nothing that you do will be applicable outside of Higher Education, the stack that you use will mostly be proprietary to a third party company, 
they use TFS but managers do not actually understand what agile means. There is very notably a culture of fear in all employees except for the friends of the CIO who are all in
upper management/director positions: the "Kaplan" crew. There is also no work from home policy, and there has not been a cost-of-living raise in over two years. 

If this sounds like an OK or Ideal place to work for you then you will fit right in, otherwise if you have any other options and any real marketable skill I suggest you steer clear of NSU. 

These are all true statements and NSU keeps paying to remove these reviews and I am fine with this.

review_title: Great company for South Florida, but going through growing pains
job_title: in Davie, FL
pros:
- NSU is one of the better companies to work for in the South Florida area as far as work environment, job stability, and pay for people who are NOT in healthcare.
- Management is very flexible about work-life balance in most departments that I can think of.
- The benefit package (health care, retirement matching plan) is pretty good, much better than what I believe most South Florida companies are offering.
- Tuition waiver is great, although I believe they changed some of the rules on that. I still think it's great because NSU offer flexibility in taking many classes online or on the weekends, so it doesn't take away from work hours.
- The work environment is pleasant, not stuffy. I find the fellow employees easy to work with in general and the middle managers easy to reach out to.
cons:
- While NSU is better than most non-healthcare companies, it is still typical of many companies in the South Florida area in that the pay doesn't match up to the cost of living of the area. The benefits are great, no doubt, but they don't pay the rent.
- Again, typical of many South Florida companies, there are not many "middle-range" jobs and therefore not many opportunities for professional growth. Some position requests masters degrees at a pay scale that a typical bachelor degree holder could easily get in another state. However, if you are someone with 10+ years and multiple degrees under your belt, NSU is great -- just not as great for a new college grad or a mid-level professional.
- NSU does give out a lot of employee surveys and tries to solve minor employee issues quickly, however they seem to avoid or circumvent larger employee complaints.

job_title: Associate Professor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Flexible schedule, good benefits and good teaching conditions
cons:
Students are "ignored", nothing counts than the executives, in HPD. All the other faculty are blue collars. There is no scientific improvement. If the supervisor is not very smart, then you are stuck! And these will track down all those colleges.
There is no diversity, no promotions and too much politics between the HPD executives and the college executives. The focus is to stop the faculty who is really good, and replace them with mediocre faculty. They will obey and will not bother the executives.
The executives are chosen for life! This is ridiculous!  
In each department of the College of Osteopathic Medicine there are faculty who left in the last 10 years, which obviously is a weakness, and BAD management.

job_title: Management In Student Services in Fort Lauderdale, FL

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Davie, FL
pros: The University is located on a very nice campus and at the time offered a nice tuition waiver program. As a former student I was hired immediately after graduation. I worked for one year with one department and a second with another while attending graduate school. In total I spent 6.5 years at NSU, the two I spent as an employee/student there were the worst.
cons:
The employees at NSU are very dissatisfied. I have heard, and continue to hear, that in order to be promoted at NSU you need to "close your mouth and put up with anything thrown at you." This includes general power struggles which often end up with staff level employees being picked on, running around doing ridiculous work, and other inane things just because someone higher up told them they had to. Why did they have to? They didn't, the higher up just felt like they could exert some power. 
The goal to succeeding at NSU is to jump through all the hoops, even if they are ridiculous. Since working in a new environment I've been treated with respect. A huge point of concern is the quickness which supervisors jump on anyone who makes a mistake. It is as if all managers wait for an opportunity to condemn someone there, which is part of the power trip which I've seen happen to many many many people. Not all mistakes (such as failing to put a comma between my first and last name on a time sheet) are horrific and world ending.
